title: Natural Resources Wales: River Llynfi pollution probe 'feeble'
content: Natural Resources Wales has been criticised after its probe into a pollution incident which killed about 45,000 fish ended without any action.NRW said it was appalled by the damage on the River Llynfi <https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-53628642>, near Pontithel, Powys, but there was "no realistic prospect of conviction".One Powys county councillor tweeted that NRW was "not fit for purpose" and another said its response was"feeble" <https://twitter.com/WmPowell2021/status/1454146741561958411>.NRW said it could consider reopening the case <https://naturalresources.wales/about-us/news-and-events/news/llynfi-pollution-investigation-ends-without-further-action-being-taken/?lang=en> if new evidence came to light.The River Llynfi, a tributary to the River Wye, is a Site of Special of Scientific Interest in a special area of conservation.In a tweet <https://twitter.com/emilyvdurrant/status/1454153463689003008>, Green Party councillor Emily Durrant said she was "devastated" by the decision, adding that NRW was "not fit for purpose if it can't even enforce a major point source pollution event like this one".This article contains content provided by Twitter. To view this content choose‘accept and continue’.Welsh Liberal Democrat councillor William Powell, a former Member of the Senedd,tweeted <https://twitter.com/WmPowell2021/status/1454146741561958411> that it was "darkest hour in the history" of the NRW as "residents... and all fair-minded people have waited patiently for justice".Ann Weedy, NRW operations manager, said: "We are very disappointed that we have not been able to bring those responsible to justice."
